Posts.Content: leprechaun wrote: Hi all, Olga had her "bloodshed" as I nicknamed it today. It's all good and normal. She's scheduled to have a CT scan on August 31st. Her recent illness and fever were indeed a banal urine tract infection and not liver mets induced as we feared and antibiotics took a good care of that. She also saw her onc. In fact, her permanent onc (a man) is now on honeymoon (yep!) so the second onc (a lady) in the pair saw Olga today. It looks like we'll restart the chemo (Carbo+Gemzar, Gemzar) in the second half of September in Carbo+Gemzar formula (without the additional Gemzar) regardless of the scan results.The onc says since Olga's disease is so aggressive and TN, it's dangerous to extend the chemo break (she's off chemo since June 25th).  Anyway, we'll wait for the scan results (September 9th) and will decide during our trip to NS. Posts.Content: leprechaun wrote: Had a meeting with the onc today. I couldn't go (my co-worker is on vacation), so Olga was accompanied by our most "pusher" friend, a biologist that is working in clinical trials herself. We had a long list of questions prepared. Our onc just loves answering questions. Q: What alternative chemos do you have right now? A: Taxotere, CMF, Navelbine, VP-16 (Etoposide) . My thoughts (MT): Olga already had Taxotere when she was Stage III two and a half years ago. CMF is only different from FEC (which she also had then) in one letter - Methotrexate instead of Epirubicin and she had FEC in 2008 too. Navelbine is known to many of you. Never heard about Etoposide,from what I found on the Web it's used in lung and testicles cancers... Not so many options, I must say... ----------------------- Q: Are there any PARP trials in Canada now? A: A trial of Iniparib shall begin in April. MT: That's something. AFAIK, this should be a Phase III study! ----------------------- Q: Any theoretical chance of getting Eribulin? A: Yes, in theory. But it's long, bureaucratic... yada yada... Notes (N): At this point our friend (her name is Olga too! :) ) interfered and asked the next question: ----------------------- Q: Would we be in the States, what you do? A: Ixabepilone, Eribulin. MT: I hate to hear the word Ixempra (Ixabepilone), two many BAD SE's... ----------------------- At this moment the two Olga's said: Q: Aha! So you'd like to try Eribulin! So will you sign the forms? A: Eh... OK, but that may take months. MT: Who cares? We're going on a PI3K Inhibitor trial anyway, right? So bring on the forms, let the bureaucratic machine start working! I already printed the forms and will fax them to the onc office tomorrow. ----------------------- Q: Lymph node in the armpit. Are you sure it's bad? Don't we want to biopsy it? A: It's probably NOT a lymph node. But I do think that's a subcutaneous met with probability of 90%. MT: Eh? Weren't you all sure Olga's lungs were overwhelmed by tumors last winter? Turned out to be an infection. He also said that shouldn't matter too much. ----------------------- Q: Can we go back on the Carbo / Gemzar if the PI3K Inhibitor doesn't work. A: Yes, but this practice usually unsuccessful. We can try that if we need though. There were a few less important questions such as menopause etc. Ah, and another thing. The PI3 Kinase Inhibitor trial coordinator called and said Olga is eligible to participate! So we'll get all the details on Monday. Thank you all for the support! Take care, Yan Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 19, 2011 07:21AM - edited May 19, 2011 07:23AM by leprechaun Olga had a chemo break last summer (see my info). She started chemo in March and got a break in June. This didn't have any effect on the chemo efficacy (same combo). You'll need some time off the chemo to gather strength for this fight. If the scans are good and your onc is thinking of it, why not? Do you eat pomegranates? They help a lot with the platelets. Also, try to find a good Iron supplement for the same reason. This kept Olga away of transfusions for several months. Take care, Yan

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2010 12:34PM leprechaun wrote: KarmaKittie, Flax is an extremely powerful antioxidant. It's able to flush the chemo down the drain because the goal of the chemo is to intoxicate the body. I don't say to avoid the flax completely, I meant, try to not eat flax on the days of the chemo and a couple of days after. Flax is full of phytoestrogen that might ignite growth of existing ER+ tumor. Actually, the studies results are mixed. Some say they are cancer free because of the diet (be it Budwig or anything else), but you never hear those who didn't succeed because they are gone. IMHO (and I completely agree with Dr. Servan-Schreiber on that) it's a crime to propagate that diet only, without chemo, can cure cancer. Period. Hope this helps, Yan

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 12:41PM - edited Mar 25, 2011 12:43PM by leprechaun Thank you Janis. Thank you all. This is so touching, beyond words. I keep telling the kids that mom's leaving doesn't mean she doesn't love them anymore. And that they can see their mom, each time they look in the mirror. I'll have to work more with the little one, he's still a little child and a concept of "never" is obscure to him. "One hundred" is an absolute maximum for him. The older son is a blessing. He knew it all even before I began explaining. The social worker that kept working with him through the last year did a marvelous job. It's so hard sometimes, especially it's so scary to wake up in the morning from a dreamless sleep into a nightmare. And the sound of a frozen ground falling on the casket is awful. And sometimes I feel I could do more, I could work faster on everything, other buttons to push, other strings to pull... But here's how I want to remember her, happy, beautiful. And healthy. She's gave a good fight.

Posts.Content: leprechaun wrote: An almost Shakespearean question. Highlights for newbies: in February my wife was almost transferred to the hospice, but then a change in treatment (switching Xeloda (useless) to Carboplatine/Gemzar (superb response)) sent her mets into retreat. Olga went today to see the onc. We are approaching the end of the chemo, the last treatment is scheduled on June 25th. On July 7th there's a CT scan. So, to make long story short, the onc is so excited with the great results of the chemo (and with the great way Olga tolerates it) he wants to extend it with two additional rounds (7 and 8) which will be very flexible in their schedule. Now, we have a dilemma. On one side, he's right. He wants to kick the bastard as hard as possible as long it's working. But on the other side, I suspect that if the chemo will be extended and stop working somewhere near its' end, we'll lose this weapon forever. Ending the chemo at June 25th  will still leave us with a chance of re-trying the same treatment later. I hope I explained the situation well enough. I see the oncs' reasoning and understand that, but there're also doubts. And tiredness. We just want to enjoy the summer together, noone knows how many of them we have left. I think we should at least wait for the CT results before making a decision. So, I'd like to know what the collective Wisdom of these boards is able to offer. You guys are such an incredible group of support, let me rely on you one more time. Thanks and take care, Yan Edited: typos, typos... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 10:04PM - edited Feb 2, 2011 10:05PM by leprechaun Cathi, Just as Elizabeth said above, the reason is obvious - Gemzar is eating your platelets. Sometimes they have to make a blood transfusion in order to revive the blood. Do you have a naturopath working with you? If you do, ask for an Iron supplement. Or ask your onc what you can do with that. My wife's platelets were pretty stable since the moment she's began with the Iron supplements (she's been on Carbo/Gemzar for almost a year). Take care, Yan

Posts.Content: leprechaun wrote: So Olga is on the short term disability now. That's almost 10 weeks already out of the maximum of 17 weeks. Some young lady from the G-W began asking questions about Olga's condition and etc. As I stated in another thread, lately she has trouble sleeping because of the worsened pain in the spine and hips, was put on the Oxycocet and will have rads starting today. Posts.Content: leprechaun wrote: An almost Shakespearean question. Highlights for newbies: in February my wife was almost transferred to the hospice, but then a change in treatment (switching Xeloda (useless) to Carboplatine/Gemzar (superb response)) sent her mets into retreat. Olga went today to see the onc. We are approaching the end of the chemo, the last treatment is scheduled on June 25th. On July 7th there's a CT scan. So, to make long story short, the onc is so excited with the great results of the chemo (and with the great way Olga tolerates it) he wants to extend it with two additional rounds (7 and 8) which will be very flexible in their schedule. Now, we have a dilemma. On one side, he's right. He wants to kick the bastard as hard as possible as long it's working. But on the other side, I suspect that if the chemo will be extended and stop working somewhere near its' end, we'll lose this weapon forever. Ending the chemo at June 25th  will still leave us with a chance of re-trying the same treatment later. I hope I explained the situation well enough. I see the oncs' reasoning and understand that, but there're also doubts. And tiredness. We just want to enjoy the summer together, noone knows how many of them we have left. I think we should at least wait for the CT results before making a decision. So, I'd like to know what the collective Wisdom of these boards is able to offer. You guys are such an incredible group of support, let me rely on you one more time. Thanks and take care, Yan Edited: typos, typos... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 10:24PM - edited Jan 11, 2011 08:42AM by leprechaun OK, thanks for your opinions. Especially you, Otter. :) Telehealth and Telemedicine are somewhat different things. The Telehealth is used when you, Barbe, call for a diagnostic opinion (we used that once with our older son and it spared us a trip to ER). Telemedicine is follow-up and routine. It can be used for education and it is used for that purpose massively here, in Ontario. But the most important issue is the ability of people to "go" to their physician who might be 1000 miles away, using the videoconferencing station. In fact, I work for the Telemedicine service provider. We're the service provider behind all the Telemedicine in the province and I personally  work in a team that takes care of the technical stuff, in particular - videoconferencing. This network is a largest and a most active Telemedicine network in the entire world (we have almost 2000 video units province-wide) and is growing at an astonishing pace. Each dollar the province gives us returns almost two. But still - only 10% of physicians are using our network. Not so many people are aware at all of such a thing. It's all secure, we use secure communication and there's an entire department dealing with privacy procedures only. We have a few programmes, such as Telestroke, Telehomecare, Teleophtalmology... but there's no usage by oncologists, almost none! Why did I come here with all this? We live an hour away from the hospital. For Olga its a burden to go there. Add to this all the psychological experience of going to the hospital (you know what I mean).  Whythe hell can't she have her follow-up appointments from home, using Telemedicine? Of course, this will not work when the appointment is diagnostic. But a lot of her appointments with the onc are only bla-bla-bla which might be done easily from home over the network. We'll start running a pilot shortly of PC-based videoconferencing (till now it was all with dedicated equipment). Then, in about 4 months, it will hopefully be rolled-out. We're discussing who should try this first. I want it so much that the oncologists will adopt it. This would save Olga and other Ontario ladies needless hours in traffic and public transit (weak immune system...). I wanted to know what you know about the Telemedicine first, because many people feel unsafe in front of the camera and a screen instead of the physician. That's why I came here asking this question. Now, my next question - would you do this? Would you trust the technology? Thanks in advance. Yan.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 02:22PM leprechaun wrote: There's a hypothesis that the Chinese people simply lack that gene responsible for an effective breakdown of milk proteins. That is why they have exorbitantly high rate of lactose intolerance. However, other races developed that gene over a course of evolution. Why? Because they began cultivating cattle for dairy thousands of years before. The same reason (but in reverse) is underlying the effective breakdown of soy proteins. Caucasian bodies can hardly process soy effectively. Unlike Asians.
